text.p: - Russia's former Prosecutor General Alexei Ilyushenko, charged with corruption earlier this year, threatens to reveal who is responsible for unleashing war in Chechnya at his trial, which is scheduled for December.
- Moscow expresses concern over the process of creating a coalition government in the breakaway republic of Chechnya as the government seems to be controlled by the separatists.
- The Russian government had to cut budget spending on investment programmes for 1997 significantly, said economy minister Yevgeny Yasin.
- Regional elections in Russia will not destroy a power balance achieved after this summer's presidential elections, says Central Electoral Committee chief Nikolai Ryabov.
- The position of Russia's prime minister Viktor Chernomyrdin has strengthened significantly, says the paper's analyst, looking at the cabinet's recent activity.

- The Russian president is like a conceited monarch- destroyer who is responsible for the people's impoverishment, collapse of the economy and national unrest and war in Chechnya, says the paper's expert in an analysis of President Yeltsin's policy and the course of economic reforns in Russia.

- It is impossible to solve the Chechen problem by force. The people fighting for its independence are invincible, says Russia's Security Council chief Alexander Lebed, answering the questions of the paper's readers.
